question: The $n^{th}$ terms of the series $3+7+13+21+...$ is

Second differences: $2, 2, \dots$
Since the second differences are constant, the $n^{th}$ term is a quadratic of the form $T_n = An^2 + Bn + C$.

$3A + B = 4 \implies 3(1) + B = 4 \implies B = 1$
$A + B + C = 3 \implies 1 + 1 + C = 3 \implies C = 1$
Therefore, $T_n = n^2 + n + 1$.

question: The remainder when $5^{99}$ is divided by 13, is
question_latex: The remainder when $5^{99}$ is divided by $13$, is
solution:
Solution:-(b) We want to find the remainder of $5^{99}$ when divided by $13$.
$5^1 \equiv 5 \pmod{13}$
$5^2 \equiv 25 \equiv 12 \equiv -1 \pmod{13}$
Now, $5^{99} = (5^2)^{49} \cdot 5^1$
$5^{99} \equiv (-1)^{49} \cdot 5 \pmod{13}$
$5^{99} \equiv -1 \cdot 5 \pmod{13}$
$5^{99} \equiv -5 \pmod{13}$
Since $-5 \equiv 8 \pmod{13}$, the remainder is $8$.

question: If $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ and $I = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, then which of the following holds for all $n \geq 1$, by the principle of mathematical induction?
question_latex: If $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ and $I = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, then which of the following holds for all $n \geq 1$, by the principle of mathematical induction?
solution:
Solution:-(d) Given, $A^n = nA - (n-1)I$
$A^2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
$nA - (n-1)I = 2A - (2-1)I = 2A - I = 2 \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
$A^3 = A^2 \cdot A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
$nA - (n-1)I = 3A - (3-1)I = 3A - 2I = 3 \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} - 2 \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
Can be verified by induction. Now, taking option $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & n \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} n & n \\ 0 & n \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} n-1 & 0 \\ 0 & n-1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & n \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
$\implies A^n = nA - (n-1)I$ is true
